text: In the nearly 60 years since the Cuban missile crisis, the story of near-catastrophe has only grown more complicated. What lessons can we draw from such a close call? https://t.co/SoDbvvdsla

text: On a new episode of #NewYorkerRadio, we discuss how the President’s encouragement of white supremacy has played out in Portland, where right-wing violence is rising fast. https://t.co/CcoA074Sf1

text: Hillary Clinton and her team assumed that they would win Wisconsin with a minimal investment but lost the state with a less-than-one-per-cent margin. This year, Joe Biden has dominated television advertising for months. https://t.co/ecgNtXjP50

text: Allowing senators to vote remotely would require a change in the standing rules of the Senate and would upend so many norms that it would likely prove incendiary—not that that would necessarily stop Mitch McConnell. https://t.co/Jd8nux5gfw

text: The pandemic has quashed much of the theatre of dining out, but the new Sichuan restaurant, offering fresh noodles, spicy beef jerky, and a seat-yourself pavilion, finds ways to be charming. https://t.co/gdmZzV3EqW

text: “What are we doing here? When the air is red and the street lights are on at noon, we ask this question. When there are 23 major fires burning at once throughout California, and 17,000 firefighters battling them, we ask this question.” https://t.co/TU6UGcJDRC

text: Great rivalries don’t always yield great matches, and Sunday’s contest between Novak Djokovic and Rafael Nadal was lopsided. https://t.co/4NrICz6gs4

text: The Van Loon House, built in 1724, had dozens of strange objects concealed in its walls—a rust-encrusted revolver, children’s shoes, pieces of quartz, and the eyeless face of a decapitated doll. https://t.co/JwYTdklmbS

name: NewYorker
text: When the coronavirus hit, Roddy Doyle was writing a book set in the present. “I stopped writing the novel I’d started; ‘the present day’ was no longer the thing it had been when I’d started it,” he said. https://t.co/0GRNISgzyS

name: NewYorker
text: “I’ve been privileged to work with some truly great, phenomenal geniuses,” Mandy Patinkin said. “And the difference, for me, is listening. The great gifted ones want to hear everything you have to say. The lesser talents don’t want to hear anything.” https://t.co/iQpttWkyt2

name: NewYorker
text: Since Joe Biden won the Democratic nomination, the election has played out mainly as a referendum on Donald Trump’s record as President—and his dissembling about the coronavirus is in plain view.  https://t.co/iFloiQju5x

name: NewYorker
text: The story of Donald Trump’s rise is often told as a hostile takeover of the G.O.P. In truth, it is something closer to a joint venture, in which members of America’s élite accepted the terms of Trumpism as the price of power. https://t.co/E8EuCNWdVE
